TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   1L NS bolus x2 given. 1unit FFP and 1unit platelets given at MN, plt ck
   post transfusion. Additional 3units FFPs and 1unit Plts given to
   maintain plt count >50 for procedure.
   -Cipro started for double coverage as patient has GNRs
   -Started tramadol b/c would not cause spasms of gallbladder sphincter
   for HIDA scan. Will give dilaudid after if he needs.
   - Hida scan showed a gallbladder that would not fill. IR would not do
   cholecystostomy b/c of coags and low platelets. Gave a 6 pack of plts.
   and 4 units of FFP. INR 2.5->2.2; Plts 47->55. Not a good response. So,
   IR would not do the procedure Friday. Agreed to re-assess Saturday
   morning. (spoke with [**Doctor Last Name 9186**]) He will get 4 units of ffp and 6
   pack of plts prior to lab draw in AM. Will likely need more after, so
   will have this order ready and hold prn. IR number [**Serial Number 9187**]

   Differential-Neuts:73.0 %, Band:12.0 %, Lymph:2.0 %, Mono:10.0 %,
   Eos:0.0 %, , Lactic Acid:5.0 mmol/L, Albumin:2.6 g/dL, LDH:147 IU/L,

   Assessment and Plan
   70 yo male with pmh of dCHF, cirrhosis, CRI, CAD, prostate cancer,
   found to have acute cholecystitis and sepsis
   # Acute cholecystitis :  . HIDA scan did not fill gallbladder,
   concerning as high pressure gallbladder needs to be removed.  Per
   surgery he is not a surgical candidiate .  IR planning on doing
   cholycystostomy today, as platelets are normalized and coags are
   normal. The differential also includes SBP (88 % polys on the
   peritoneal fluid differential) and GNR in peritoneum
   -  Cholecystostomy today per IR. Will reserve 4 units of FFP and 1 bag
   of platelets prior to procedure.
   -  Continue double coverage for pseudomonas with cipro and zosyn and
   continue empiric vanc until final cultures return
   -  IVF boluses prn for MAPs < 65. Patient has not required
   pressors..will continue to monitor. If BP not controlled, consider
   starting levophed
   -  PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Zofran prn for nausea
   -  Ultram for pain; if significant pain, will give prn dilaudid.
   #  Sepsis:  Lactate still significantly elevated at 5, but coming
   down.  Most likely secondary to infection.  Potential infectious
   sources include biliary infection from acute cholecystitis (also
   causing secondary bacterial peritonitis), SBP,
   - Volume resuscitation with goal UOP 30 cc/hr and MAPs > 65 and CVP
   12-14 goal
   - Treatment with broad spectrum antibiotics (vanc and zosyn, cipro)
   while cultures are pending.
   - Will trend WBC and lactate.
   - F/u culture data.
   #  Change in mental status:  Per report from the ED, his family thought
   he had change in mental status.  On exam here he was oriented, but he
   has unknown baseline.  In the setting of his acute illness and
   decreased bowel movements most likely his change in mental status was
   due to hepatic encephalopathy.  Also in the differential is delirium or
   infection (UTI, SBP, bacteremia). Patient currently clear and oriented
   throughout the night.
   - Clarify baseline with family in the am.
   - Treatment of possible hepatic encephalopathy with lactulose
   - UCx pending.  F/U blood cultures and peritoneal cultures
   #  Cirrhosis secondary to NASH:  The patient has known cirrhosis
   complicated by encephalopathy requiring lactulose.  He has current
   evidence of synthetic dysfunction with an INR of 1.8.
   - PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - As above, lactulose for treatment of likely hepatic encephalopathy.
   - Holding aldactone, lasix, and nadolol due to potential for him to
   drop his blood pressures if he becomes septic.
   - Consider adding midodrine and octreotide
   #  Metabolic acidosis:  The patient has an anion gap of 13, but a low
   albumin around 2.8 so he has a slight anion gap metabolic acidosis as
   well as a non-anion gap acidosis.  His gap acidosis is likely from
   lactic acidosis (he had a lactate of 5.8).  He had the non-gap acidosis
   on presentation to the OSH and his Cl is not elevated so unlikely
   secondary to NS resuscitation.  Possibly due to bicarb loss from
   frequent stools secondary to lactulose.
   - Recheck panel and switch to D5 with bicarb if acidemic from NS as
   liver patient
s can
t metabolize bicarb in LR
makes them more acidemic
   - Trend lactate
   #  Hyponatremia:  Per OSH records the patient's Na was 126, now 133
   here.  Was found to be dry at the OSH and given IVF.  As his Na is
   correcting with volume repletion, likely hypovolemic hyponatremia.
   - Continue to trend.
   #  Thrombocytopenia:  The patient's plt are at 52 which per the OSH
   records is near his baseline.  Likely secondary to cirrhosis.
   - Continue to trend.
   - Transfuse platelets as needed
   #  Acute on Chronic renal insufficiency:  Unclear baseline; Cr is
   reportedly at his baseline of 1.5, however in OMR in [**2180**] he had a
   normal Cr of 0.8.  His K was initially high, but has normalized. FeUrea
   was 5.7% c/w pre-renal etiology from septic picture
   - IVFs to maintain appropriate MAPS > 65 and UOP > 30 cc/hr
   - Trend Cr
    - Avoid nephrotoxins and renally dose medications.
   #  Hx of CAD/dCHF:  EKG was without ischemic changes.  No active chest
   pain currently.  Patient appears volume depleted on exam.
   - Not on CAD/CHF regimen as an outpatient.
   - Will consider a TTE to assess cardiac function if he hasn't had a
   recent one at [**Hospital3 2851**].
   #  DMII:
   - While NPO will give [**12-13**] his regular home insulin regimen.
   - Monitor with qid finger sticks.
   #  Prostate cancer: On hormonal therapy as an outpatient.
   #  Hypothyroidism:
   - Continue outpatient levothyroxine.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO, replete electrolytes
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2183-9-12**] 05:18 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2183-9-12**] 05:19 AM
   Right IJ: placed [**2183-9-12**]
   A-line placed [**2183-9-12**]
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots due to  previous HIT antibody
   Stress ulcer:  PPI
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: patient wants to wait for daughter (HCP) to discuss, Full
   code for now
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, coronary artery disease, and prostate cancer, who was admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis and sepsis. He has been treated with antibiotics and is scheduled for a cholecystostomy procedure. The patient has a significant lactate elevation, likely secondary to infection, and is being treated with volume resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotics. He also has evidence of hepatic encephalopathy and is being treated with lactulose. The patient's platelet count is low, likely due to cirrhosis, and he is being transfused as needed.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's lactate elevation and low platelet count suggest ongoing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's elevated lactate levels and low platelet count increase the risk of hepatic encephalopathy, which can lead to altered mental status, seizures, and coma.
3. Renal Insufficiency: The patient's chronic renal insufficiency and low albumin levels increase the risk of acute kidney injury, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's low platelet count and elevated INR suggest coagulopathy, which can lead to bleeding complications.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient's decreased air movement and low oxygen saturation levels increase the risk of respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia and respiratory acidosis.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and chronic heart failure increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of cirrhosis and acute cholecystitis increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.
8. Infection: The patient's sepsis and low platelet count increase the risk of secondary infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and central line-associated bloodstream infections.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent and manage these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, coronary artery disease, and prostate cancer. He was admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and suspected gallbladder perforation. His laboratory results show evidence of liver dysfunction, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. He has a lactate level of 5 mmol/L, indicating septic shock.

The patient's medical history includes cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, coronary artery disease, and prostate cancer. He has been treated with hormonal therapy for his prostate cancer and is currently taking levothyroxine for hypothyroidism.

The patient's current condition is critical, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15, indicating a moderate level of consciousness. He has a fever of 38.6°C, tachycardia, and tachypnea. His blood pressure is 107/53 mmHg, and his central venous pressure (CVP) is 12-14 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of liver dysfunction, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 54 U/L, an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 97 U/L, and an alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level of 57 U/L. His bilirubin level is 3.7 mg/dL, and his international normalized ratio (INR) is 1.8.

The patient's platelet count is 52,000/μL, and his white blood cell count is 8,300/μL. His creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 26 mg/dL.

The patient's medical condition is complicated by the presence of cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, and sepsis. He requires close monitoring and management of his blood pressure, central venous pressure, and lactate level. He also requires antibiotics, fluids, and vasopressors to treat his sepsis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is severe, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent organ dysfunction and death.
2. Liver failure: The patient's liver dysfunction is severe, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent liver failure and death.
3. Kidney failure: The patient's kidney dysfunction is severe, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent kidney failure and death.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiovascular condition is complicated by the presence of cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, and sepsis, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent cardiovascular complications.
5. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory condition is complicated by the presence of sepsis, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent respiratory complications.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological condition is complicated by the presence of sepsis, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent neurological complications.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastrointestinal condition is complicated by the presence of sepsis, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent gastrointestinal complications.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent organ dysfunction and death. He requires antibiotics, fluids, and vasopressors to treat his sepsis. He also requires close monitoring of his blood pressure, central venous pressure, and lactate level. He requires a multidisciplinary approach to care, including input from intensivists, gastroenterologists, and nephrologists.

   70 yo male with pmh of dCHF, cirrhosis, CRI, CAD, prostate cancer,
   found to have acute cholecystitis and sepsis
   #  Sepsis:  Lactate trending down after cholecystostomy.  Sepsis
   secondary to bacterial peritonitis secondary to gallbladder infection.
   SBP (88 % polys on the peritoneal fluid differential) as GNR in
   peritoneal fluid
   - Volume resuscitation with goal UOP 30 cc/hr and MAPs > 65 and CVP
   12-14 goal
   - Treatment with broad spectrum antibiotics (vanc and zosyn, cipro)
   while cultures are pending.
   - Will trend WBC and lactate.
   - F/u culture data.
   # Acute cholecystitis:  s/p cholycystostomy by IR on [**9-13**].
   -  Continue double coverage for pseudomonas with cipro and zosyn and
   continue empiric vanc until final cultures return
   -  PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Zofran prn for nausea
   -  If significant pain, will give prn dilaudid.
   # Respiratory Distress:  Increased O2 requirement to non-rebreather.
   - get ABG
   - CXR
   - EKG to look for signs of ischemic changes
   - consider lasix trial due to hx of diastolic dysfunction, and pt has
   received lots of fluids since admission to [**Hospital Unit Name 4**]
   #  Altered mental status:  Family had noted initial change in mental
   status, possibly secondary to sepsis.  On exam here he was oriented,
   but unknown baseline.  Likely has some hepatic encephalopathy,
   particularly because not having bowel movements, and he is dependent on
   lactulose at home.  Pt oriented currently but somewhat somnolent.
   Somnolence may also be due to hypercarbia.
   - Clarify baseline with family .
   - Continue lactulose for probability of some hepatic encephalopathy
   - UCx pending.  F/U blood cultures and peritoneal cultures
   #  Cirrhosis secondary to NASH:  The patient has known cirrhosis
   complicated by encephalopathy requiring lactulose.  He has current
   evidence of synthetic dysfunction with an increasing INR.
   - PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - As above, continue lactulose for treatment of likely hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - Restarted nadolol overnight
   - Holding aldactone, lasix due to potential for him to drop his blood
   pressures if he becomes septic.
   # Atrial Fibrillation:  Ventricular rates in upper 90s and lower 100s
   overnight, but more controlled now.  No signs of hemodynamic
   instability
   - restarted home nadolol though not used for BP and HR
   # Anemia: Acute drop likely in the setting of fluid resuscitation.
   Patient at high risk for bleeding. DIC labs negative
   - Guaiac stools
   - Monitor Hcts, especially after procedure.
   #  Thrombocytopenia:  The patient's plt are at 45, baseline in 50s,
   likely secondary to cirrhosis.
   - Continue to trend.
   - Transfuse platelets to greater than 50.
   #  Acute on Chronic renal insufficiency:  Unclear baseline; Cr is
   reportedly at his baseline of 1.2 (however in OMR in [**2180**] he had a
   normal Cr of 0.8).  K was initially high, but has normalized. FeUrea
   was 5.7% c/w pre-renal etiology from septic picture
   - IVFs to maintain appropriate MAPS > 65 and UOP > 30 cc/hr
   - Trend Cr
    - Avoid nephrotoxins and renally dose medications.
   - Consider midorine and octreotide if hepatorenal becomes concerning.
   #  Hx of CAD/dCHF:  EKG was without ischemic changes.  No active chest
   pain currently.  Patient appears volume depleted on exam.
   - Not on CAD/CHF regimen as an outpatient.
   - Will consider a TTE to assess cardiac function if he hasn't had a
   recent one at [**Hospital3 2851**].
   #  DMII:
   - While NPO will give [**12-13**] his regular home insulin regimen.
   - Monitor with qid finger sticks.
   #  Prostate cancer: On hormonal therapy as an outpatient.
   #  Hypothyroidism:
   - Continue outpatient levothyroxine.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, coronary artery disease, prostate cancer, and diabetes mellitus type 2. He was admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and respiratory distress. He underwent paracentesis and cholecystostomy, and is currently receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is receiving oxygen therapy and has an increased oxygen requirement. His ABG results are pending.
* Cardiovascular: He has atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate in the upper 90s and lower 100s. His blood pressure is 107/53 mmHg, and his central venous pressure is 7 mmHg.
* Renal: He has acute on chronic renal insufficiency, and his creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL. He is receiving IV fluids to maintain adequate blood pressure and urine output.
* Hepatic: He has cirrhosis secondary to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, and is receiving lactulose for treatment of likely hepatic encephalopathy.
* Hematological: He has thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 45. He is at high risk for bleeding, and is receiving platelet transfusions.
* Neurological: He has altered mental status, which may be secondary to sepsis, hypercarbia, or hepatic encephalopathy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen if his infection is not properly managed.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's increased oxygen requirement and respiratory distress may lead to respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if his cardiac function is not properly managed.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal insufficiency may worsen if his kidney function is not properly managed.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's likely hepatic encephalopathy may worsen if his liver function is not properly managed.
6. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and high risk for bleeding may lead to bleeding complications.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if his blood loss is not properly managed.

Plan:

1. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with broad-spectrum antibiotics and fluids.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide oxygen therapy as needed.
3. Manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with rate control and anticoagulation therapy.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and provide IV fluids and diuretics as needed.
5. Manage the patient's hepatic encephalopathy with lactulose and other medications as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and provide platelet transfusions as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's anemia and provide blood transfusions as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure, cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, CAD, prostate cancer, and hypothyroidism, who was admitted with acute cholecystitis and sepsis. He underwent cholecystostomy and is currently being treated with antibiotics and fluids. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 109 bpm, blood pressure of 107/53 mmHg, and SpO2 of 94%. He has a positive fluid wave in his abdomen and is tender to palpation throughout. His laboratory results show an elevated lactate level, which is trending down, and his blood cultures are pending.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely secondary to bacterial peritonitis, and he is at risk of developing further complications such as organ dysfunction, shock, and death.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's chronic renal insufficiency may worsen due to his sepsis and fluid resuscitation, leading to acute kidney injury.
3. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis and ascites may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause altered mental status, confusion, and coma.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require mechanical ventilation to support his breathing.
5. Hemorrhagic Complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy may increase his risk of bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient's CAD and chronic heart failure may worsen due to his sepsis and fluid resuscitation, leading to cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.
7. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's lactic acidosis may worsen due to his sepsis and inadequate tissue perfusion, leading to metabolic acidosis.
8. Thrombotic Complications: The patient's cirrhosis and thrombocytopenia may increase his risk of thrombotic complications, such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
9. Infection: The patient's sepsis may lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
10. Organ Failure: The patient's sepsis may lead to organ failure, including respiratory, cardiac, renal, or hepatic failure.

   # Acute cholecystitis:  s/p cholycystostomy by IR on [**9-13**].

   #  Sepsis:  Lactate still significantly elevated at 5, but started
   trending down yesterday.  Most likely secondary to bacterial
   peritonitis secondary to gallbladder infection.  SBP (88 % polys on the
   peritoneal fluid differential) as GNR in peritoneal fluid
   - Volume resuscitation with goal UOP 30 cc/hr and MAPs > 65 and CVP
   12-14 goal
   - Treatment with broad spectrum antibiotics (vanc and zosyn, cipro)
   while cultures are pending.
   - Will trend WBC and lactate.
   - F/u culture data.
   #  Altered mental status:  Family had noted initial change in mental
   status, possibly secondary to sepsis.  On exam here he was oriented,
   but unknown baseline.  Likely has some hepatic encephalopathy,
   particularly because not having bowel movements, and he is dependent on
   lactulose at home.  Pt clear and oriented currently
   - Clarify baseline with family .
   - Continue lactulose for probability of some hepatic encephalopathy
   - UCx pending.  F/U blood cultures and peritoneal cultures
   #  Cirrhosis secondary to NASH:  The patient has known cirrhosis
   complicated by encephalopathy requiring lactulose.  He has current
   evidence of synthetic dysfunction with an increasing INR.
   - PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - As above, continue lactulose for treatment of likely hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - Restarted nadolol overnight
   - Holding aldactone, lasix due to potential for him to drop his blood
   pressures if he becomes septic.
   - Increasing oxygen requirements, likely from ascitic fluid. Will
   monitor after pericentesis today.
   # Atrial Fibrillation:  Ventricular rates in upper 90s and lower 100s
   overnight, but more controlled now.  No signs of hemodynamic
   instability
   - restarted home nadolol though not used for BP and HR
   # Anemia: Acute drop likely in the setting of fluid resuscitation.
   Patient at high risk for bleeding. DIC labs negative
   - Guaiac stools
   - Monitor Hcts, especially after procedure.
   #  Metabolic acidosis:  Presented w lactic Acidosis and likely nongap
   acidosis from diarrhea in addition to probable primary respiratory
   alkalosis from cirrhotic disease. No longer has gap acidosis.
   - Continue to monitor and switch to D5 with bicarb if acidemic from NS

s can
t metabolize bicarb in LR
   - Trend lactate

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus type II, and prostate cancer, who was admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis and sepsis.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.2°C (99°F)
* Heart rate: 109 bpm
* Blood pressure: 107/53 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 94%
* CVP: 7 mmHg

The patient has been receiving empiric antibiotics for suspected pseudomonas infection, and the cultures are pending. The patient's lactate levels are still elevated at 5.0 mmol/L, but are trending down.

The patient's abdominal examination reveals a positive fluid wave, and the cholecystostomy tube is draining brown liquid. The patient has not had a bowel movement since the morning of the 13th.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.3 K/μL
* Hematocrit: 40.8%
* Platelet count: 47 K/μL
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 5.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 189 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.7 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Ciprofloxacin
* Zosyn
* Vancomycin
* Nadolol
* Fentanyl
* Morphine
* Lactulose
* PPI
* Zofran

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing empiric antibiotics for suspected pseudomonas infection
* Monitoring lactate levels and trending WBC and platelet counts
* F/u culture data
* Clarifying baseline mental status with family
* Continuing lactulose for probable hepatic encephalopathy
* Restarting nadolol
* Holding aldactone and lasix due to potential for blood pressure drop
* Increasing oxygen requirements, likely from ascitic fluid

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Acute kidney injury due to fluid resuscitation and sepsis
* Hepatic encephalopathy due to cirrhosis and liver dysfunction
* Respiratory failure due to ascitic fluid and sepsis
* Thrombocytopenia and bleeding due to cirrhosis and liver dysfunction
* Metabolic acidosis due to lactic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to atrial fibrillation and electrolyte imbalance
* GI bleeding due to ascitic fluid and sepsis

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and medication regimen to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis, admitted to the ICU with sepsis secondary to cholecystitis and bacterial peritonitis. The patient has undergone drainage of the biliary system (gallbladder) and therapeutic paracentesis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 37.6°C (99.7°F), Tcurrent 37°C (98.6°F), HR 79 bpm, BP 107/53 mmHg, RR 17 insp/min, SpO2 95%.
* Laboratory results: WBC 8.3, Hct 40.8, Plt 47, Cr 1.8, TropT 0.01, TCO2 23, Glucose 164.
* Physical examination: Overweight/obese, normocephalic, cardiac examination normal, peripheral vascular examination normal, respiratory/chest examination symmetric expansion, percussion dullness, breath sounds diminished, abdominal soft, no tenderness, tender RUQ mild, neurologic examination attentive, follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, movement and tone not assessed.

The patient's conditions and potential medical complications are:

1. Sepsis: The patient remains off pressors and has required only mildly positive fluid balance. He has been treated with Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro, and the culture results are pending.
2. Cholecystitis: The patient has similar findings on liver-associated enzymes in the setting of known cirrhosis. The drainage will be maintained pending resolution.
3. Cirrhosis of the liver: The patient has a history of cirrhosis, and lactulose will be continued to manage the condition.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is being managed with Nadolol, and his rate is well-controlled.
5. Renal failure: The patient has a history of chronic renal failure, and his renal function is reassuring.
6. Ascites: The patient has ascites, which is being managed with drainage.
7. Potential complications: The patient is at risk for further complications such as:
	* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
	* Cholecystitis-related complications (e.g., biliary peritonitis, abscess)
	* Cirrhosis-related complications (e.g., bleeding, encephalopathy)
	* Atrial fibrillation-related complications (e.g., stroke, cardiac arrest)
	* Renal failure-related complications (e.g., acute kidney injury, uremia)
	* Ascites-related complications (e.g., infection, bleeding)

The plan of care for the patient includes:

1. Continued management of sepsis with Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro and follow-up culture results.
2. Maintenance of drainage for cholecystitis.
3. Continuation of lactulose for cirrhosis management.
4. Maintenance of Nadolol for atrial fibrillation management.
5. Monitoring of renal function and management of ascites.
6. Consideration of further interventions, such as antibiotic therapy, surgical intervention, or other treatments, as needed.

   Assessment and Plan
   70 yo male with pmh of dCHF, cirrhosis, CRI, CAD, prostate cancer,
   found to have acute cholecystitis s/p cholecystostomy and intubation.
   Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: s/p Intubation [**9-14**].  CXR today with ?
   atelectasis versus pleural effusions
   -          Esoaphageal balloon study to evaluate pleural pressures.
   -          Pending esophageal balloon study, consider pericentesis
   today to drain ascites as this will help his fluid overload
   -          Consider lasix to decrease pulmonary effusions
   #  Sepsis:  Sepsis secondary to bacterial peritonitis secondary to
   cholecystitis with GNR in peritoneal fluid, now speciated to E. Coli
   susceptible to zosyn, resistant to cipro.
   - Volume resuscitation with goal UOP 30 cc/hr and MAPs > 65 and CVP
   12-14 goal
   - Was started on vanc, zosyn, cipro pending cultures.  Can d/c cipro
   and vanc given cultures with E. Coli.
   - Will trend WBC and lactate.
   - F/u culture data
   - repeat blood culture, send sputum culture and repeat peritoneal
   culture if pericentesis today
   # Acute cholecystitis:  s/p cholycystostomy by IR on [**9-13**].  Output
   dark brown.
   -  Continue zosyn and d/c vanc and cipro as above
   -  will check KUB per surgery recs
   -  PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Zofran prn for nausea
   -  If significant pain, will give prn dilaudid.
   #  Acute on Chronic renal insufficiency:  Unclear baseline; Cr is
   reportedly at his baseline of 1.2 (however in OMR in [**2180**] he had a
   normal Cr of 0.8).  Cr now increasing, likely due to combination
   intravascular volume depletion, phenylephrine, and ? abdominal
   compartment syndrome.  K was initially high, but has normalized. FeUrea
   was 5.7% c/w pre-renal etiology from septic picture
   - IVFs to maintain appropriate MAPS > 65 and UOP > 30 cc/hr.  Will hold
   for now pending results from bladder pressure and esophageal balloon
   study
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins and renally dose medications.
   - will check bladder pressure to evaluate for component of abdominal
   compartment syndrome and consider pericentesis if bladder pressure > 20
   cm H2O
   - Consider midorine and octreotide if hepatorenal becomes concerning.
   # Atrial Fibrillation:  Ventricular rates in upper 90s and lower 100s
   overnight, but more controlled now.  No signs of hemodynamic
   instability
   - restarted home nadolol though not used for BP and HR.  D/C nadolol
   now given HR well-controlled and other potential causes for minimal
   tachycardia
   #  Cirrhosis secondary to NASH:  The patient has known cirrhosis
   complicated by encephalopathy requiring lactulose.  He has current
   evidence of synthetic dysfunction with an increasing INR.
   - PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Trend platelets, coags and LFTs
   - Pericentesis today if elevated bladder/pleural pressure
   - Continue lactulose for treatment of likely hepatic encephalopathy.
   Add Erythromycin for gastric motility.  Goal [**3-16**] BMs today
   - Hold nadolol for now
   - Holding aldactone for now
   #  Altered mental status:  Family had noted initial change in mental
   status, possibly secondary to sepsis.  On exam here he was oriented,
   but unknown baseline.  Likely has some hepatic encephalopathy,
   particularly because not having bowel movements, and he is dependent on
   lactulose at home.  Pt oriented currently but somewhat somnolent.
   Somnolence may also be due to hypercarbia.
   - Clarify baseline with family .
   - Continue lactulose for probability of some hepatic encephalopathy
   - F/U urine, blood and peritoneal cultures
   - check ammonia
   # Anemia: Acute drop likely in the setting of fluid resuscitation.
   Patient at high risk for bleeding. DIC labs negative. HCT now
   improving, likely secondary to intravascular volume depletion in
   setting of worse ascites
   - Guaiac stools
   - Monitor Hcts, especially after procedure.
   #  Thrombocytopenia:  Plts now 108
   - continue to trend
   #  Hx of CAD/dCHF:  EKG was without ischemic changes.  No active chest
   pain currently.  Patient appears volume depleted on exam.
   - Not on CAD/CHF regimen as an outpatient.  Will consider starting
   outpatient regimen once present clinical picture improves.
   - Will consider a TTE to assess cardiac function if he hasn't had a
   recent one at [**Hospital3 2851**].
   #  DMII:
   - While NPO will give [**12-13**] his regular home insulin regimen.
   - Monitor with qid finger sticks.
   #  Prostate cancer: Stable. On hormonal therapy as an outpatient.
   #  Hypothyroidism:
   - Continue outpatient levothyroxine.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: OG tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  standing insulin + sliding scale
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2183-9-12**] 07:50 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2183-9-12**] 10:00 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2183-9-13**] 08:02 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Pneumoboots due to  previous HIT antibody
   Stress ulcer:  PPI
   VAP:
   Comments: Communication: - family notified-- note: w further changes in
   status, pls notify daughter first and let her contact her mother; pt's
   wife was getting distraught over news of intubation over phone,
   thinking that he was not going to make it, and daughter feels as though
   she doesn't understand well and would rather explain to her mother
   herself
   [**Name2 (NI) 156**] status: Full code for now (per daughter, HCP)
   Disposition: ICU

   Assessment and Plan
   70 yo male with pmh of dCHF, cirrhosis, CRI, CAD, prostate cancer,
   found to have acute cholecystitis s/p cholecystostomy and intubation.
   Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: s/p Intubation [**9-14**].  CXR today with ?
   atelectasis versus pleural effusions
   -          Esoaphageal balloon study to evaluate pleural pressures.
   -          Pending esophageal balloon study, consider pericentesis
   today to drain ascites as this will help his fluid overload
   -          Consider lasix to decrease pulmonary effusions
   #  Sepsis:  Sepsis secondary to bacterial peritonitis secondary to
   cholecystitis with GNR in peritoneal fluid, now speciated to E. Coli
   susceptible to zosyn, resistant to cipro.
   - Volume resuscitation with goal UOP 30 cc/hr and MAPs > 65 and CVP
   12-14 goal
   - Was started on vanc, zosyn, cipro pending cultures.  Can d/c cipro
   and vanc given cultures with E. Coli.
   - Will trend WBC and lactate.
   - F/u culture data
   - repeat blood culture, send sputum culture and repeat peritoneal
   culture if pericentesis today
   # Acute cholecystitis:  s/p cholycystostomy by IR on [**9-13**].  Output
   dark brown.
   -  Continue zosyn and d/c vanc and cipro as above
   -  will check KUB per surgery recs
   -  PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Zofran prn for nausea
   -  If significant pain, will give prn dilaudid.
   #  Acute on Chronic renal insufficiency:  Unclear baseline; Cr is
   reportedly at his baseline of 1.2 (however in OMR in [**2180**] he had a
   normal Cr of 0.8).  Cr now increasing, likely due to combination
   intravascular volume depletion, phenylephrine, and ? abdominal
   compartment syndrome.  K was initially high, but has normalized. FeUrea
   was 5.7% c/w pre-renal etiology from septic picture
   - IVFs to maintain appropriate MAPS > 65 and UOP > 30 cc/hr.  Will hold
   for now pending results from bladder pressure and esophageal balloon
   study
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins and renally dose medications.
   - will check bladder pressure to evaluate for component of abdominal
   compartment syndrome and consider pericentesis if bladder pressure > 20
   cm H2O
   - Consider midorine and octreotide if hepatorenal becomes concerning.
   # Atrial Fibrillation:  Ventricular rates in upper 90s and lower 100s
   overnight, but more controlled now.  No signs of hemodynamic
   instability
   - restarted home nadolol though not used for BP and HR.  D/C nadolol
   now given HR well-controlled and other potential causes for minimal
   tachycardia
   #  Cirrhosis secondary to NASH:  The patient has known cirrhosis
   complicated by encephalopathy requiring lactulose.  He has current
   evidence of synthetic dysfunction with an increasing INR.
   - PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Trend platelets, coags and LFTs
   - Pericentesis today if elevated bladder/pleural pressure
   - Continue lactulose for treatment of likely hepatic encephalopathy.
   Add Erythromycin for gastric motility.  Goal [**3-16**] BMs today
   - Hold nadolol for now
   - Holding aldactone for now
   #  Altered mental status:  Family had noted initial change in mental
   status, possibly secondary to sepsis.  On exam here he was oriented,
   but unknown baseline.  Likely has some hepatic encephalopathy,
   particularly because not having bowel movements, and he is dependent on
   lactulose at home.  Pt oriented currently but somewhat somnolent.
   Somnolence may also be due to hypercarbia.
   - Clarify baseline with family .
   - Continue lactulose for probability of some hepatic encephalopathy
   - F/U urine, blood and peritoneal cultures
   - check ammonia
   # Anemia: Acute drop likely in the setting of fluid resuscitation.
   Patient at high risk for bleeding. DIC labs negative. HCT now
   improving, likely secondary to intravascular volume depletion in
   setting of worse ascites
   - Guaiac stools
   - Monitor Hcts, especially after procedure.
   #  Thrombocytopenia:  Plts now 108
   - continue to trend
   #  Hx of CAD/dCHF:  EKG was without ischemic changes.  No active chest
   pain currently.  Patient appears volume depleted on exam.
   - Not on CAD/CHF regimen as an outpatient.  Will consider starting
   outpatient regimen once present clinical picture improves.
   - Will consider a TTE to assess cardiac function if he hasn't had a
   recent one at [**Hospital3 2851**].
   #  DMII:
   - While NPO will give [**12-13**] his regular home insulin regimen.
   - Monitor with qid finger sticks.
   #  Prostate cancer: Stable. On hormonal therapy as an outpatient.
   #  Hypothyroidism:
   - Continue outpatient levothyroxine.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure, cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, coronary artery disease, prostate cancer, and diabetes mellitus type II. He was admitted with acute cholecystitis and was treated with cholecystostomy and intubation. The patient has developed sepsis secondary to bacterial peritonitis, acute on chronic renal insufficiency, atrial fibrillation, cirrhosis, and altered mental status.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory: Hypoxic respiratory failure, intubated and ventilated
* Cardiovascular: Atrial fibrillation, hypotension
* Renal: Acute on chronic renal insufficiency, increasing creatinine
* Hepatic: Cirrhosis, encephalopathy
* Hematological: Thrombocytopenia, anemia
* Infectious: Sepsis, bacterial peritonitis

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory: Pneumonia, respiratory failure, ventilator-associated pneumonia
2. Cardiovascular: Cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, cardiogenic shock
3. Renal: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease progression
4. Hepatic: Hepatic encephalopathy, liver failure
5. Hematological: Bleeding, disseminated intravascular coagulation
6. Infectious: Sepsis, septic shock, organ failure
7. Neurological: Increased intracranial pressure, seizures
8. Gastrointestinal: Gastrointestinal bleeding, bowel obstruction
9. Endocrine: Hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia
10. Cardiovascular: Cardiac arrest, cardiac tamponade

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Adjust fluid management to maintain a balance between fluid resuscitation and preventing fluid overload.
3. Consider pericentesis to drain ascites and pleural effusions.
4. Continue antibiotic therapy for sepsis and bacterial peritonitis.
5. Monitor for signs of cardiac arrhythmias and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Consider initiating cardioprotective medications to prevent cardiac complications.
7. Monitor for signs of bleeding and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
8. Consider initiating therapy to prevent and treat gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Monitor for signs of increased intracranial pressure and seizures.
10. Consider initiating therapy to prevent and treat endocrine complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, atrial fibrillation, and prostate cancer. The patient was admitted with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and hypoxic respiratory failure, requiring intubation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated, on assisted ventilation with a tidal volume of 450cc, and a PEEP of 10 cmH2O. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is taking nadolol for rate control. He has a decreased ejection fraction and is at risk for cardiac failure.
* Renal: The patient has chronic renal insufficiency and is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) due to sepsis and fluid overload.
* Hepatic: The patient has cirrhosis secondary to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and is at risk for hepatic encephalopathy and portal hypertension.
* Hematological: The patient has thrombocytopenia and is at risk for bleeding due to his low platelet count and history of cirrhosis.
* Endocrine: The patient has diabetes mellitus type II and is at risk for hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.

The patient's current medications include:

* Lasix for fluid overload
* Vanc for sepsis
* Zosyn for bacterial peritonitis
* Cipro for bacterial peritonitis
* Midazolam for sedation
* Fentanyl for pain management
* Phenylephrine for blood pressure support
* Lactulose for hepatic encephalopathy
* PPI for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Levothyroxine for hypothyroidism

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Hepatic encephalopathy
* Portal hypertension
* Bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
* Cardiac failure
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Pericentesis to drain ascites and improve respiratory function
* Continuous monitoring of vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation
* Monitoring of laboratory values, including complete blood count, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine
* Adjustment of medications as needed to manage the patient's condition
* Close monitoring for signs of sepsis and respiratory failure
* Consideration of a tracheostomy if the patient requires prolonged mechanical ventilation.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure, cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, CAD, prostate cancer, and hypothyroidism, who was admitted with nausea, vomiting, and RUQ abdominal pain. He was found to have acute cholecystitis and was treated with cholecystostomy and intubation. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has been diagnosed with hypoxic respiratory failure, sepsis, acute cholecystitis, acute on chronic renal insufficiency, atrial fibrillation, cirrhosis, altered mental status, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and history of CAD/dCHF, DMII, and prostate cancer.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing septic shock due to the presence of GNR in the peritoneal fluid and the patient's compromised immune system.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration due to the presence of bilateral atelectasis and pleural effusion.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and there is a risk of further deterioration due to the presence of sepsis, hypotension, and nephrotoxic medications.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient has a history of cirrhosis and is at risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy due to the presence of ascites and the patient's compromised liver function.
5. Bleeding: The patient is at risk of bleeding due to the presence of thrombocytopenia and the patient's compromised coagulation profile.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CAD and dCHF, and there is a risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and cardiogenic shock.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing further infections due to the presence of indwelling lines and tubes, and the patient's compromised immune system.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient is at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding, perforation, and obstruction due to the presence of ascites and the patient's compromised gastrointestinal function.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and fluids, and monitor for signs of septic shock.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust fluid management and medications as necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hepatic encephalopathy with lactulose and monitor for signs of worsening encephalopathy.
5. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust medications and treatments as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust antibiotics and other treatments as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient for signs of gastrointestinal complications and adjust treatments as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure, cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, CAD, prostate cancer, and hypothyroidism. He was admitted with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and respiratory failure. He underwent cholecystostomy and was intubated due to hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient has been experiencing nausea, vomiting, and RUQ abdominal pain.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis secondary to bacterial peritonitis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires mechanical ventilation. He is at risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's baseline creatinine level is unclear, but his current level is elevated. He is at risk of developing AKI due to sepsis, hypovolemia, and nephrotoxic medications.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient has cirrhosis and is at risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy, which can lead to altered mental status, seizures, and coma.
5. Bleeding: The patient has thrombocytopenia and is at risk of bleeding due to his liver disease and anticoagulant therapy.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CAD and CHF, and his current cardiac status is uncertain. He is at risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and heart failure.
7. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and wound infections, due to his compromised immune system.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of cirrhosis and is at risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding, ascites, and encephalopathy.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is at risk of developing nutritional deficiencies due to his altered gut function, malabsorption, and inadequate nutrition.
10. Psychiatric complications: The patient's altered mental status and sedation can lead to psychiatric complications, including anxiety, depression, and psychosis.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and management. The plan includes:

1. Continued mechanical ventilation to support his respiratory status.
2. Aggressive fluid resuscitation to correct hypovolemia and improve renal function.
3. Antibiotic therapy to treat sepsis and prevent further infections.
4. Management of his liver disease, including lactulose therapy for hepatic encephalopathy.
5. Monitoring of his cardiac status, including echocardiography and cardiac enzymes.
6. Management of his bleeding risk, including platelet transfusions and anticoagulant therapy.
7. Nutritional support, including total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or enteral nutrition.
8. Close monitoring of his mental status and psychiatric symptoms.
9. Regular reassessment of his condition and adjustments to his treatment plan as needed.

   normal Cr of 0.8).  K was initially high, but has normalized. FeUrea

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic heart failure, cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, CAD, prostate cancer, and hypothyroidism. He was admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and hypoxic respiratory failure. He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation to improve his respiratory status. He has been receiving treatment for his conditions, including antibiotics, diuretics, and vasopressors.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for septic shock due to his bacteremia and Gram-negative rods in his peritoneal fluid.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's baseline creatinine level is unclear, but his current level is 1.6 mg/dL, which may indicate acute kidney injury.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis and elevated INR suggest that he may be at risk for hepatic encephalopathy, which could worsen his mental status.
4. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy may increase his risk of bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen his respiratory status and require further interventions.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and chronic heart failure may increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
7. Infection: The patient's bacteremia and Gram-negative rods in his peritoneal fluid may indicate a systemic infection that requires further evaluation and treatment.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The plan includes:

1. Continued treatment for sepsis, including antibiotics and vasopressors.
2. Management of his acute kidney injury, including IV fluids and diuretics.
3. Treatment for his hepatic encephalopathy, including lactulose and rifaximin.
4. Monitoring of his bleeding risk, including platelet transfusions and coagulation factor replacement.
5. Management of his respiratory failure, including mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
6. Evaluation and treatment of his cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and heart failure.
7. Infection control measures, including antibiotic stewardship and infection surveillance.

   culture if pericentesis today

   -  Continue zosyn and d/c vanc and cipro as above
   -  PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Zofran prn for nausea
   -  If significant pain, will give prn dilaudid.

   reportedly at his baseline of 1.2 (however in OMR in [**2180**] he had a
   normal Cr of 0.8).  Cr now increasing K was initially high, but has
   normalized. FeUrea was 5.7% c/w pre-renal etiology from septic picture

   - F/U urine, blood and peritoneal cultures
   # Anemia: Acute drop likely in the setting of fluid resuscitation.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure, cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, CAD, prostate cancer, and hypothyroidism, who was admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and hypoxic respiratory failure. He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. The patient has been receiving antibiotics, vasopressors, and diuretics to manage his condition. He also has a cholecystostomy tube in place to drain his gallbladder.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing septic shock due to his underlying cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, and hypothyroidism, which can impair his immune function.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen if he develops further lung complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis and underlying liver dysfunction may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause altered mental status, confusion, and decreased responsiveness.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's chronic renal insufficiency may worsen if he develops acute kidney injury (AKI) due to sepsis, hypovolemia, or nephrotoxic medications.
5. Bleeding Complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy may increase his risk of bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient's underlying CAD and chronic heart failure may worsen if he develops further cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiogenic shock.
7. Infection: The patient's sepsis and underlying immunocompromise may increase his risk of developing further infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or bloodstream infection.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's acute cholecystitis and underlying cirrhosis may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
9. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status and underlying liver dysfunction may increase his risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures, encephalopathy, or stroke.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   70 yo male with pmh of dCHF, cirrhosis, CRI, CAD, prostate cancer,
   found to have acute cholecystitis s/p cholecystostomy and intubation.
   Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: s/p Intubation [**9-14**].  CXR today with ?
   atelectasis versus pleural effusions
   -          Esoaphageal balloon study to evaluate pleural pressures.
   -          Pending esophageal balloon study, consider pericentesis
   today to drain ascites as this will help his fluid overload
   -          Consider lasix to decrease pulmonary effusions
   #  Sepsis:  Sepsis secondary to bacterial peritonitis secondary to
   cholecystitis with GNR in peritoneal fluid, now speciated to E. Coli
   susceptible to zosyn, resistant to cipro.
   - Volume resuscitation with goal UOP 30 cc/hr and MAPs > 65 and CVP
   12-14 goal
   - Was started on vanc, zosyn, cipro pending cultures.  Can d/c cipro
   and vanc given cultures with E. Coli.
   - Will trend WBC and lactate.
   - F/u culture data
   - repeat blood culture, send sputum culture and repeat peritoneal
   culture if pericentesis today
   # Acute cholecystitis:  s/p cholycystostomy by IR on [**9-13**].  Output
   dark brown.
   -  Continue zosyn and d/c vanc and cipro as above
   -  will check KUB per surgery recs
   -  PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Zofran prn for nausea
   -  If significant pain, will give prn dilaudid.
   #  Acute on Chronic renal insufficiency:  Unclear baseline; Cr is
   reportedly at his baseline of 1.2 (however in OMR in [**2180**] he had a
   normal Cr of 0.8).  Cr now increasing, likely due to combination
   intravascular volume depletion, phenylephrine, and ? abdominal
   compartment syndrome.  K was initially high, but has normalized. FeUrea
   was 5.7% c/w pre-renal etiology from septic picture
   - IVFs to maintain appropriate MAPS > 65 and UOP > 30 cc/hr.  Will hold
   for now pending results from bladder pressure and esophageal balloon
   study
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins and renally dose medications.
   - will check bladder pressure to evaluate for component of abdominal
   compartment syndrome and consider pericentesis if bladder pressure > 20
   cm H2O
   - Consider midorine and octreotide if hepatorenal becomes concerning.
   # Atrial Fibrillation:  Ventricular rates in upper 90s and lower 100s
   overnight, but more controlled now.  No signs of hemodynamic
   instability
   - restarted home nadolol though not used for BP and HR.  D/C nadolol
   now given HR well-controlled and other potential causes for minimal
   tachycardia
   #  Cirrhosis secondary to NASH:  The patient has known cirrhosis
   complicated by encephalopathy requiring lactulose.  He has current
   evidence of synthetic dysfunction with an increasing INR.
   - PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Trend platelets, coags and LFTs
   - Pericentesis today if elevated bladder/pleural pressure
   - Continue lactulose for treatment of likely hepatic encephalopathy.
   Add Erythromycin for gastric motility.  Goal [**3-16**] BMs today
   - Hold nadolol for now
   - Holding aldactone for now
   #  Altered mental status:  Family had noted initial change in mental
   status, possibly secondary to sepsis.  On exam here he was oriented,
   but unknown baseline.  Likely has some hepatic encephalopathy,
   particularly because not having bowel movements, and he is dependent on
   lactulose at home.  Pt oriented currently but somewhat somnolent.
   Somnolence may also be due to hypercarbia.
   - Clarify baseline with family .
   - Continue lactulose for probability of some hepatic encephalopathy
   - F/U urine, blood and peritoneal cultures
   - check ammonia
   # Anemia: Acute drop likely in the setting of fluid resuscitation.
   Patient at high risk for bleeding. DIC labs negative. HCT now
   improving, likely secondary to intravascular volume depletion in
   setting of worse ascites
   - Guaiac stools
   - Monitor Hcts, especially after procedure.
   #  Thrombocytopenia:  Plts now 108
   - continue to trend
   #  Hx of CAD/dCHF:  EKG was without ischemic changes.  No active chest
   pain currently.  Patient appears volume depleted on exam.
   - Not on CAD/CHF regimen as an outpatient.  Will consider starting
   outpatient regimen once present clinical picture improves.
   - Will consider a TTE to assess cardiac function if he hasn't had a
   recent one at [**Hospital3 2851**].
   #  DMII:
   - While NPO will give [**12-13**] his regular home insulin regimen.
   - Monitor with qid finger sticks.
   #  Prostate cancer: Stable. On hormonal therapy as an outpatient.
   #  Hypothyroidism:
   - Continue outpatient levothyroxine.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: OG tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  standing insulin + sliding scale

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and acute on chronic renal insufficiency. He has a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, coronary artery disease, heart failure, prostate cancer, and diabetes mellitus type II. He was intubated due to hypoxic respiratory failure and is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a pleural effusion and ascites, which is causing respiratory distress. He is also experiencing abdominal compartment syndrome, which is contributing to his renal insufficiency.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis secondary to bacterial peritonitis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk of developing ARDS, which can lead to respiratory failure and death.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is deteriorating, and he is at risk of developing AKI, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
4. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient has cirrhosis and is at risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy, which can lead to altered mental status, seizures, and coma.
5. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: The patient has abdominal compartment syndrome, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not treated promptly and effectively.
6. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk of developing pneumonia due to his respiratory status and the presence of a foreign body (endotracheal tube) in his airway.
7. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk of developing DVT due to his immobility and the presence of central venous catheters.
8. Stress Ulcer Bleeding: The patient is at risk of developing stress ulcer bleeding due to his critical illness and the use of corticosteroids.
9. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk of developing VAP due to the presence of a foreign body (endotracheal tube) in his airway and the use of mechanical ventilation.

The patient requires close monitoring and aggressive management of his medical conditions to prevent these potential complications and improve his outcomes.

   -          Esoaphageal balloon study to evaluate pleural pressures.

   culture if pericentesis today

   -  PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Zofran prn for nausea
   -  If significant pain, will give prn dilaudid.

   reportedly at his baseline of 1.2 (however in OMR in [**2180**] he had a
   normal Cr of 0.8).  Cr now increasing, likely due to combination
   intravascular volume depletion, phenylephrine, and ? abdominal
   compartment syndrome.  K was initially high, but has normalized. FeUrea
   was 5.7% c/w pre-renal etiology from septic picture
   - IVFs to maintain appropriate MAPS > 65 and UOP > 30 cc/hr.  Will hold
   for now pending results from bladder pressure and esophageal balloon
   study
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins and renally dose medications.
   - will check bladder pressure to evaluate for component of abdominal
   compartment syndrome and consider pericentesis if bladder pressure > 20
   cm H2O
   - Consider midorine and octreotide if hepatorenal becomes concerning.
   # Atrial Fibrillation:  Ventricular rates in upper 90s and lower 100s
   overnight, but more controlled now.  No signs of hemodynamic
   instability
   - restarted home nadolol though not used for BP and HR.  D/C nadolol
   now given HR well-controlled and other potential causes for minimal
   tachycardia
   #  Cirrhosis secondary to NASH:  The patient has known cirrhosis

   - PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Trend platelets, coags and LFTs

   - Continue lactulose for treatment of likely hepatic encephalopathy.

   - check ammonia

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure, cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, coronary artery disease, prostate cancer, and hypothyroidism, who was admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and respiratory failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His laboratory results show evidence of bacterial peritonitis with E. coli, and he has been started on Zosyn. He has also been diagnosed with acute on chronic renal insufficiency, atrial fibrillation, and altered mental status, likely due to sepsis and hepatic encephalopathy. He is at risk for bleeding, and his platelet count is decreasing.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to the presence of bacterial peritonitis and the possibility of further infection.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
3. Renal insufficiency: The patient's kidney function is compromised, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
4. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to his thrombocytopenia and the presence of sepsis.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's mental status is altered, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
6. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome is a potential complication of his sepsis and fluid overload.
7. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for developing pneumonia due to his intubation and mechanical ventilation.
8. Catheter-related bloodstream infections: The patient has multiple central lines, which increases his risk for catheter-related bloodstream infections.
9. Acute kidney injury: The patient's kidney function is compromised, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
10. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular status is unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and fluids.
3. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
4. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust his platelet transfusion strategy accordingly.
5. Continue to treat the patient's hepatic encephalopathy with lactulose and consider adding other medications as needed.
6. Consider performing a pericentesis to drain the patient's ascites and relieve his abdominal compartment syndrome.
7. Consider performing a TTE to assess the patient's cardiac function.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his sedation and analgesia accordingly.
9. Consider adding other medications to the patient's regimen as needed to manage his symptoms and prevent complications.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history, including cholecystitis, hypotension, acute renal failure, cirrhosis, and chronic respiratory failure. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and antibiotics.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine levels, suggesting ongoing sepsis and acute kidney injury. The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and the patient has evidence of gram-negative bacteremia.

The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with a respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 94%, and arterial blood gas values consistent with chronic respiratory acidosis. The patient's chest radiograph shows moderate atelectasis in the left lung.

The patient's cardiovascular status is also concerning, with hypotension and low intravascular filling pressures. The patient's central venous pressure is elevated, suggesting high pleural pressure due to tense ascites and weight.

The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome is a significant concern, with decreased urine output and elevated creatinine levels. The patient's bladder pressure should be assessed, and paracentesis is necessary to manage the ascites.

The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia. The patient's calcium levels are normal.

The patient's medical team is considering switching vasopressors, as phenylephrine may further compromise renal perfusion. The patient is also at risk for bleeding due to his coagulopathy.

The patient's nutrition is being managed with tube feeding, and glycemic control is being maintained with regular insulin sliding scale. The patient's lines include a multi-lumen line, 20-gauge line, and arterial line.

The patient's prophylaxis includes DVT boots, stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI, and VAP prevention measures. The patient's status is full code, and his disposition is ICU.

In summary, the patient is critically ill with a complex medical history, and his condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, coronary artery disease, and prostate cancer. He was admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and hypoxic respiratory failure.

Current medical issues:

1. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis secondary to bacterial peritonitis caused by E. coli, which is susceptible to Zosyn.
2. Acute cholecystitis: The patient had a cholecystostomy procedure on [**9-13**] and is still experiencing dark brown output.
3. Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine is increasing, likely due to intravascular volume depletion, phenylephrine, and abdominal compartment syndrome.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's ventricular rate is controlled, but he has a history of atrial fibrillation.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient has known cirrhosis complicated by encephalopathy, requiring lactulose.
6. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is altered, possibly due to sepsis, hepatic encephalopathy, or hypercarbia.
7. Anemia: The patient has acute anemia, likely due to fluid resuscitation.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is improving.
9. Coronary artery disease: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and is at high risk for bleeding.
10. Prostate cancer: The patient has stable prostate cancer and is on hormonal therapy.
11. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism and is on levothyroxine.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing further complications from sepsis, such as organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest.
2. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome may worsen, leading to increased intracranial pressure, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's hepatic encephalopathy may worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease, requiring dialysis.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease may lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
6. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and history of coronary artery disease put him at high risk for bleeding, which may worsen his condition.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue antibiotics for sepsis and acute cholecystitis.
2. Monitor the patient's abdominal compartment syndrome and consider pericentesis if necessary.
3. Trend the patient's creatinine and consider dialysis if necessary.
4. Continue lactulose for hepatic encephalopathy and monitor the patient's mental status.
5. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and consider platelet transfusions if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider starting outpatient cardiac therapy once his clinical picture improves.
7. Consider a TTE to assess cardiac function if the patient has not had a recent one.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and consider platelet transfusions if necessary.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's hypothyroidism and adjust his levothyroxine dose as necessary.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical issues, including sepsis, acute cholecystitis, acute on chronic renal insufficiency, atrial fibrillation, cirrhosis, altered mental status, anemia, thrombocytopenia, coronary artery disease, prostate cancer, and hypothyroidism. The patient is at risk of developing further complications, including sepsis, abdominal compartment syndrome, hepatic encephalopathy, renal failure, cardiac complications, and bleeding. A comprehensive plan is necessary to manage the patient's complex medical issues and prevent further complications.

   cholecystitis with GNR in peritoneal fluid, now speciated to E. Coli
   susceptible to zosyn, resistant to cipro.  WBC trending down.
   Afebrile.
   - Volume resuscitation difficult given liver failure and ascites
   - Was started on vanc, zosyn, cipro pending cultures.  Can d/c cipro
   and vanc and continue zosyn given cultures with E. Coli.

   non-diagnostic.  Pain decreasing.

   -  Zofran prn for nausea
   -  If significant pain, will give prn dilaudid.
   #  Acute on Chronic renal insufficiency:  Unclear baseline; Cr was
   increasing, likely due to combination intravascular volume depletion,
   phenylephrine, and abdominal compartment syndrome.  Cr now trending
   down s/p tap + fluid bolus with albumin.  K was initially high, but has
   normalized. FeUrea was 5.7% c/w pre-renal etiology from septic picture
   - Trend Cr and U/O with goal u/o > 30 cc/hr
   - if Cr increase or u/o decrease, reassess abdominal exam, bladder

   #  Cirrhosis secondary to NASH:  The patient has known cirrhosis
   complicated by encephalopathy requiring lactulose.  He has current

   trending down slightly, T. bili increasing slightly, ascites improved.
   Massive diarrhea on lactulose and erythromycin yesterday requiring

   - continue lactulose, goal [**3-16**] BMs per day

   particularly because not having bowel movements, and he is dependent on

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a complex medical history, including decompensated heart failure, cirrhosis, chronic renal insufficiency, coronary artery disease, prostate cancer, and hypothyroidism. He was admitted to the ICU with acute cholecystitis, sepsis, and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxic respiratory failure, intubated and ventilated with a PRVC/AC mode, PEEP 12 cmH2O, FiO2 50%, and SpO2 96%.
* Cardiovascular: Atrial fibrillation, ventricular rate 60s to 80s, no signs of hemodynamic instability.
* Renal: Acute on chronic renal insufficiency, Cr trending down after fluid bolus with albumin, goal u/o > 30 cc/hr.
* Hepatic: Cirrhosis secondary to NASH, evidence of synthetic dysfunction, AST/ALT trending down slightly, T. bili increasing slightly, ascites improved.
* Neurological: Altered mental status, possibly secondary to sepsis, oriented but somewhat somnolent, likely has some hepatic encephalopathy.
* Hematological: Anemia, thrombocytopenia, platelet count 45 from 108.
* Endocrine: DMII, FS well-controlled on home insulin regimen, now high 200s with tube feeds.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis secondary to bacterial peritonitis, and further complications can arise if the infection is not effectively managed.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is already intubated and ventilated, and further complications can arise if the respiratory failure is not managed effectively.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient has acute on chronic renal insufficiency, and further complications can arise if the kidney injury is not managed effectively.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient has cirrhosis and evidence of synthetic dysfunction, and further complications can arise if the hepatic encephalopathy is not managed effectively.
5. Bleeding: The patient has a high risk of bleeding due to anemia and thrombocytopenia, and further complications can arise if bleeding is not managed effectively.
6. Infection: The patient has multiple lines and tubes in place, and further complications can arise if infection develops.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, and further complications can arise if the condition is not managed effectively.
8. Prostate cancer: The patient has prostate cancer, and further complications can arise if the cancer progresses.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following interventions should be considered:

1. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis and respiratory failure effectively.
2. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust fluid management accordingly.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hepatic encephalopathy and cirrhosis.
4. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust anticoagulation therapy accordingly.
5. Monitor the patient's infection risk and adjust prophylaxis accordingly.
6. Continue to manage the patient's hypothyroidism and prostate cancer.
7. Consider starting the patient on outpatient regimens for CAD/CHF and DMII once the patient's clinical picture improves.

You are a Medical Specialist capable of analyzing complex medical cases. To do that, you will carefully review the physician's daily progress note for a patient in the ICU detailing the patient's health progress in the ICU. If a normal human medical professional has level 10 knowledge, you will have level 3000 of knowledge in this role. As it's crucial for the patient's well-being, please ensure accurate assessments because if you don't, the patient's condition could worsen. Take pride in your work and give it your best.    found to have acute cholecystitis s/p cholecystostomy and intubation.
   Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: s/p Intubation [**9-14**].  CXR yesterday with ?

   cholecystitis with GNR in peritoneal fluid, now speciated to E. Coli
   susceptible to zosyn, resistant to cipro.
   - Volume resuscitation with goal UOP 30 cc/hr and MAPs > 65 and CVP
   12-14 goal
   - Was started on vanc, zosyn, cipro pending cultures.  Can d/c cipro
   and vanc given cultures with E. Coli.
   - Will trend WBC and lactate.
   - F/u culture data
   - repeat blood culture, send sputum culture and repeat peritoneal
   culture if pericentesis today
   # Acute cholecystitis:  s/p cholycystostomy by IR on [**9-13**].  Output
   dark brown.
   -  Continue zosyn and d/c vanc and cipro as above
   -  will check KUB per surgery recs
   -  PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Zofran prn for nausea
   -  If significant pain, will give prn dilaudid.
   #  Acute on Chronic renal insufficiency:  Unclear baseline; Cr is
   reportedly at his baseline of 1.2 (however in OMR in [**2180**] he had a
   normal Cr of 0.8).  Cr now increasing, likely due to combination
   intravascular volume depletion, phenylephrine, and ? abdominal
   compartment syndrome.  K was initially high, but has normalized. FeUrea
   was 5.7% c/w pre-renal etiology from septic picture
   - IVFs to maintain appropriate MAPS > 65 and UOP > 30 cc/hr.  Will hold
   for now pending results from bladder pressure and esophageal balloon
   study
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins and renally dose medications.
   - will check bladder pressure to evaluate for component of abdominal
   compartment syndrome and consider pericentesis if bladder pressure > 20
   cm H2O
   - Consider midorine and octreotide if hepatorenal becomes concerning.
   # Atrial Fibrillation:  Ventricular rates in upper 90s and lower 100s
   overnight, but more controlled now.  No signs of hemodynamic
   instability
   - restarted home nadolol though not used for BP and HR.  D/C nadolol
   now given HR well-controlled and other potential causes for minimal
   tachycardia
   #  Cirrhosis secondary to NASH:  The patient has known cirrhosis
   complicated by encephalopathy requiring lactulose.  He has current
   evidence of synthetic dysfunction with an increasing INR.
   - PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Trend platelets, coags and LFTs
   - Pericentesis today if elevated bladder/pleural pressure
   - Continue lactulose for treatment of likely hepatic encephalopathy.
   Add Erythromycin for gastric motility.  Goal [**3-16**] BMs today
   - Hold nadolol for now
   - Holding aldactone for now
